title: Delivering data transformative investments
body: The FAIR data toolbox contains key resources that can help everyone deliver data transformative investments. Discover more about each below:

_items.title: The FAIR data mark scheme (7 questions)
_items.body:
This FAIR data mark scheme presents seven key questions and accompanying mark scheme to assess if grants are data transformative.

Use it to:

  • Help assess how integrated FAIR and safeguarded data is within the design of an investment when completing the FAIR & safeguarded data integration marker.
  • Understand what good practice looks like for access, use and sharing of data in grants  
  • Identify where grantees may need to take further action to ensure data they access, use and share is shared as widely as possible

The FAIR data mark scheme also provides the basis for the FAIR data integration marker as well as questions generated by the INVEST system to be answered within a grant proposal.

_items.title: Learning resources (7 eLearning modules)
_items.body:
To accompany the seven questions in the FAIR data mark scheme are 7 eLearning modules, one for each question. These are:

Module 1: Delivering data transformative investments (this one)
Module 2: Assessing in country policies and laws to support data sharing
Module 3: Working with data from multiple sources
Module 4: Protecting rights of individuals while maximising the utility of data
Module 5: Data sharing to maximise utility
Module 6: Minimising harmful impacts from data
Module 7: Building sustainable data ecosystems

Each is available to everyone, both POs and Grantees, in the toolbox.

_items.title: Tools and checklists to support investments
_items.body:
To support the delivery of data transformative investments a set of checklists, practical guides and tools are also available in the toolbox. These are designed to support the seven questions in the FAIR data mark scheme, examples are:

  • Checklist: Identifying data rich grants
  • Risk assessment: Personal data
  • Practical guide: Anonymisation
  • Practical guide: Choosing a licence for data
  • Tools: The data ethics canvas

_items.title: Case studies
_items.body: Being able to demonstrate the benefits of FAIR and transformative data is key to supporting everyone. The toolbox contains a number of case studies on initiatives from around the world.

_items.title: Specialist support
_items.body: While the FAIR data toolbox is self-serve, we have also listed a set of external support organisations and individuals that can help with all aspects of delivering data transformative investments.

title: Introduction
body:
Fears over collecting, using and sharing personal data often results in data not getting to those who need it. The challenge starts with understanding just what personal data is, the difference between this and sensitive commercial and the role of data protection regulations which many see as a blocker to sharing personal data. 

The aim of this module is to increase understanding of personal data and techniques that can be applied to ensure data transformative investments protect the rights of individuals while maximising the utility of data.

_graphic.attribution: Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation [All rights reserved]

title: Topics
body:
This module introduces:

  • The differences between personal, sensitive personal and sensitive commercial data
  • The importance of understanding who owns personal data
  • The rights of individuals over personal data
  • The role of data protection regulations
  • Techniques to reduce the risks of handling personal data
  • Tools, checklists and case studies to support investments

title: Classifying personal and sensitive data
instruction: Select your answer from the drop downs. When done click 'submit'

_items.text: A person's name
A person's religion
A shop's income
The location of a soil sample

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

As an easy to remember rule, any data or information directly relating to an identifiable individual is personal, including pictures of a person, or group, of people. 

Sensitive personal data is that which affords extra protection due to its nature, e.g. genetic data, health records or data that can potentially be used to discriminate, such as religion, sexual orientation and race. 

Any data not relating to a person, such as income of a business and locations of things, is not personal but it may be deemed commercially sensitive.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

As an easy to remember rule, any data or information directly relating to an identifiable individual is personal, including pictures of a person, or group, of people. 

Sensitive personal data is that which affords extra protection due to its nature, e.g. genetic data, health records or data that can potentially be used to discriminate, such as religion, sexual orientation and race. 

Any data not relating to a person, such as income of a business and locations of things, is not personal but it may be deemed commercially sensitive.

title: Defining personal, sensitive personal and sensitive commercial data
body:
Personal data: Information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person.

Sensitive personal data: Personal data that affords extra protection due to its nature, e.g. genetic data, health records or data that can potentially be used to discriminate.

Sensitive commercial data: Non-personal data, such as income of a business and locations of things. It is often deemed sensitive as the use and sharing of data may still result in harmful impacts.

In all cases countries will likely have their own definitions and categories for personal and sensitive personal data defined by data protection regulations. Sensitive commercial data may not be as well defined. It is the responsibility of those handling such data to take necessary steps to minimising harmful impacts.

title: Defining personal, sensitive personal and sensitive commercial data
Who owns personal data?
body: Can you correctly identify the owner of the following?
instruction: Select your answers from the drop downs. When done click 'submit'

_items.text: A tweet you write
Your fracebook profile picture
A field survey you conduct

_options.text: The people the survey is about

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Providing there is an intellectual effort in creating something, the person who put in the effort in the creation is the owner. 

So your the tweets you write, a photograph you take, a spreadsheet you create, these are all owned by you. 

In the case where you interact with a survey, platform or service, the owner of the data created as a result of your interaction will be the service provider, e.g. the research institute or the social media platform. This is because the intellectual effort in the creation of the survey or service is the provider, you are simply interacting with it.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Providing there is an intellectual effort in creating something, the person who put in the effort in the creation is the owner. 

So your the tweets you write, a photograph you take, a spreadsheet you create, these are all owned by you. 

In the case where you interact with a survey, platform or service, the owner of the data created as a result of your interaction will be the service provider, e.g. the research institute or the social media platform. This is because the intellectual effort in the creation of the survey or service is the provider, you are simply interacting with it.

title: The importance of understanding who owns personal data
body:
Not all data about you is your data; you do do own it all. But because it is about you, you have rights over it, and this is why we have data protection regulations; to protect the rights of individuals. 

Around the world many countries have been updating data protection regulations to account for people now interacting online. In an increasingly frictionless data world, clear guidance needs to be in place on not just what individuals rights are over data about them but also the lawful basis for using, storing and retaining personal data, both in country and internationally. 

Data protection regulations are not there to prevent data reaching those who need it, they are there to protect the privacy and rights of the people the data is about.

title: The importance of understanding who owns personal data
Knowing your rights
body: Under modern data protection regulations, such as the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), what rights do individuals have over data about them?

_items.text: The right to be informed how data about them is processed
The right to access data about them
The right to object or withdraw consent
All of the above

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Regardless of how data is collected or processed, individuals have the right to be informed about how data about them is processed and for what purpose. 

In many situations, especially where consent is used as a lawful basis for processing personal data, individuals also have the right to access, rectify or even object to data about them being stored and processed.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Regardless of how data is collected or processed, individuals have the right to be informed about how data about them is processed and for what purpose. 

In many situations, especially where consent is used as a lawful basis for processing personal data, individuals also have the right to access, rectify or even object to data about them being stored and processed.

title: The rights of individuals over personal data

_items.title: Right to be informed
_items.body: Individuals have the right to be informed about how personal data about them is collected and used. This information should be presented in a privacy notice. This should be presented to the individual when data is collected, in clear, concise language and be easily accessible.

_items.title: Right to access (subject access requests)
_items.body: The right to access gives people the right to request a copy of the personal information about them. There are expectations to this, such as when that information is being used for criminal proceedings or other sensitive legal obligation.

_items.title: Right to rectification
_items.body: Individuals have the right to have personal data corrected if it is inaccurate or incomplete. The data controller also has responsibilities to ensure the data is corrected if it is shared with others.

_items.title: Right to be forgotten
_items.body: The right to be forgotten (or the right to data erasure) entitles an individual to direct the controller to erase personal data about them, cease further sharing of the data, and potentially halt processing of the data by third parties.

_items.title: Right to restrict processing
_items.body:
Individuals have a right to ‘block’ or suppress processing of personal data. 

Such rights can be exercised when:

  • the accuracy of the personal data is contested
  • where the individual has objected to the processing (only in the case of performance of a public task or legitimate interest)
  • the processing is unlawful
  • the data is needed for future reference but should no longer be processed

_items.title: Right to data portability
_items.body: Individuals can request that personal data about them be transferred directly to another controller. To this point, we have only seen the financial sector adopt the right to data portability as a way to build better banking services. The global open banking initiative allows customers to directly transfer personal data between financial service providers, meaning you can change bank without having to fill in endless forms.

_items.title: Right to object or withdraw consent
_items.body: If the lawful basis for processing is based on having consent, the individual has the right to withdraw that consent at any time. The process of withdrawing consent must be as easy as giving consent in the first place. If a different lawful basis other than consent is being used as the basis for processing personal data, individuals may have the right to object to that processing.

_items.title: Right to not be subject solely to automated decision making
_items.body: Individuals have the right to not be subject to a decision based solely on automated processing, including profiling. In all cases individuals must be informed about the automated processing and be able to request human intervention or challenge a decision.

title: The role of data protection regulations
body:
Generally data protection regulations set out the following: 

  1. Definitions of personal and sensitive personal data
  2. Geographic restrictions relating specifically to personal data
  3. The lawful basis under which personal data can be processed
  4. The rights of individuals over personal data about them
  5. The responsibilities of data controllers in relation to personal data

title: The role of data protection regulations
body:
Different countries have their own data protection legislation, which enable personal data to be used while protecting the rights of individuals. The most important thing to remember is that personal data cannot be collected or processed without a lawful basis; if no lawful basis applies then it is illegal to hold the personal data.

A lawful basis is often detailed as part of the data governance and privacy impact assessments and should also be clear to individuals as part of the privacy notice.

Once the lawful basis is established, all other aspects, such as rights of individuals will be matched to this.

title: Techniques to reduce the risks of handling personal data
body: What steps can be taken to reduce the risks of handling personal data?

_items.text: Not collecting personal data in the first place
Anonymise the data, removing any personal information
Delete the personal information, or create a synthetic dataset of fictional people
All of the above

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Personal data should only be collected and stored if it is absolutely necessary to fulfil the lawful basis. If you don’t need it, don’t collect it. The same applies to retaining personal data. 

As an alternative to deleting data, anonymisation techniques could be applied that remove any personal data that can identify a specific individual. 

Alternatively you could consider creating a synthetic dataset. A synthetic dataset contains many of the statistical patterns of an original dataset, but does not refer to identifiable individuals (e.g. it contains fictional people), thereby reducing the risk of re identification.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Personal data should only be collected and stored if it is absolutely necessary to fulfil the lawful basis. If you don’t need it, don’t collect it. The same applies to retaining personal data. 

As an alternative to deleting data, anonymisation techniques could be applied that remove any personal data that can identify a specific individual. 

Alternatively you could consider creating a synthetic dataset. A synthetic dataset contains many of the statistical patterns of an original dataset, but does not refer to identifiable individuals (e.g. it contains fictional people), thereby reducing the risk of re identification.

title: Techniques to reduce the risks of handling personal data
Data protection and anonymised/synthentic data
body: Do data protection regulations apply to anonymised or synthetic data?

_items.text: Yes
No

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Once the data is anonymised, data protection regulations no longer apply and data can be shared with others safely, even outside of geographical boundaries that may be imposed by data protection regulations.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Once the data is anonymised, data protection regulations no longer apply and data can be shared with others safely, even outside of geographical boundaries that may be imposed by data protection regulations.

title: Summary
body:
Fears over collecting, using and sharing personal data often results in data not getting to those who need it. The challenge starts with understanding just what personal data is, the difference between this and sensitive commercial and the role of data protection regulations which many see as a blocker to sharing personal data.

Increasing understanding of personal data, data protection regulations and techniques that can be applied minimise the risks of handling personal data is essential to ensure data transformative investments protect the rights of individuals while maximising the utility of data.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]

title: The rights of individuals over personal data
body:
Regardless of how data is collected or processed, individuals have the right to be informed about how data about them is processed and for what purpose. Further, this must be specific. Privacy notices stating that personal data is used to “improve the level of service” are no longer valid under modern data protection regulations, like GDPR, as these are not specific.

Additionally the following rights are emerging globally, both as part of data protection regulations and also as best practices even when relating to non-personal data.

title: Tools, checklists and case studies to support investments
displayTitle: Tools, checklists and case studies to support investments
body:
To support the delivery of data transformative investments while protecting the rights of individuals a set of checklists, practical guides and tools are also available in the toolbox. These include:

  • Risk assessment: Personal data
  • Practical guide: Anonymisation
  • Practical guide: Agricultural data country briefing on data policy, legal and regulatory context 
  • Tools: The data ethics canvas

Case studies

To demonstrate how others have navigated the collection, use and sharing of personal data we have included a case study within the FAIR data toolbox.

Specialist support

While the FAIR data toolbox is self-serve, we have also listed a set of external support organisations and individuals that can help with protecting the rights of individuals and all aspects of delivering data transformative investments.

title: Introduction
body:
The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation is committed to information sharing and transparency. In order to deliver on this commitment it is critical to ensure data and information collected, accessed, used or shared within investments is FAIR and safeguarded. That is, data that is Findable, Accessible, Interoperable and Reusable to as many people as possible. 

The aim of this module is to enable the identification of activities that are likely to generate and use data and understand the challenges that need to be overcome in order to deliver FAIR and safeguarded data within investments.

For both Program Officers (POs) and grantees this module is designed to help understanding of the requirements for integrating FAIR and safeguarded data within an investment, making the grant process smoother and results more impactful.

_graphic.attribution: Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation [All rights reserved]

title: Why FAIR and safeguarded data?
body: The aim of FAIR and safeguarded data within investments is to…?

_items.text: Ensure fair and equitable access to data
Boost return on investment in data rich grants through wider data sharing
Protect the rights and interests of individuals affected by the collection, use and sharing of data
All of the above

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

FAIR and safeguarded data within an investment focuses on making data as open as possible, while minimising harmful impacts. 

Access to data is not always equitable and the rights and interests of individuals affected by the collection, use and sharing of data are not always considered. This restricts the value that can be created from data, limiting its use in decision making, and the potential return on investments.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

FAIR and safeguarded data within an investment focuses on making data as open as possible, while minimising harmful impacts. 

Access to data is not always equitable and the rights and interests of individuals affected by the collection, use and sharing of data are not always considered. This restricts the value that can be created from data, limiting its use in decision making, and the potential return on investments.

title: Why FAIR and safeguarded data within investments is critical to realise BMGF aims
Why data transformation is critical to realise wider BMGF aims
body:
The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation is committed to information sharing and transparency. In order to deliver on this commitment it is critical to ensure data and information collected, accessed, used or shared within investments is FAIR and safeguarded.

Currently, digitally-enabled services rely on sustainable access to relevant data, provided in a way that enables integration, analysis and use to reduce risk and improve decisions. Data is often not shared or managed well, which means that the Gates Foundation does not receive the highest possible return from investments and the value that can be created from data is not realised.

title: What makes data FAIR and safeguarded?
What makes data FAIR and safeguarded?
body:
Value can be created from data when it is collected, accessed, used and shared. Maximising the value created from data can only be achieved when all of these aspects are considered. However this cycle is often broken as data is not shared and thus the same data cannot be collected and re-used by others. 

FAIR data is that which is Findable, Accessible, Interoperable and Reusable by others. 

Safeguarded data is managed and sustained equitably and ethically; making it as open as possible while reducing harmful impacts.

title: Delivering FAIR and safeguarded data within investments
body: What is required to support delivery of FAIR and safeguarded data within investments?

_items.text: A set of technologies, standards and platforms
Well defined processes and policies around data
People to lead, support and advocate for FAIR and transformative data
All of the above

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Key to ensuring data is FAIR and safeguarded are the people, policies and processes that support the use of technology; you need to maintain equal focus on all aspects to maximise the utility of data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Key to ensuring data is FAIR and safeguarded are the people, policies and processes that support the use of technology; you need to maintain equal focus on all aspects to maximise the utility of data.

title: Delivering FAIR and safeguarded data within investments
Topics
body:
This module introduces:

  • Why FAIR and safeguarded data within investments is critical to realise wider BMGF aims
  • What makes data FAIR and safeguarded
  • Common constraints in delivering FAIR and safeguarded data investments
  • Examples of FAIR and safeguarded data investments
  • How to identify investments that should integrate FAIR and safeguarded data 
  • The roles and responsibilities of BMGF project officers and grantees in delivering FAIR and safeguarded data investments
  • Resources to help deliver FAIR and safeguarded data investments investments

title: People, Process and Technology
body: Key to ensuring data is FAIR and safeguarded are the people, policies and processes that support the use of technology; you need to maintain equal focus on all aspects to maximise the utility of data.

title: Common barriers
body: Which of the following are common barriers to delivering FAIR and safeguarded data within investments?

_items.text: Concerns over data security and privacy
A mis-trust in data or others use of data
No suitable technology to make use of data
No data available

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Cultural resistance to sharing data, driven by concerns of data security and mis-trust in data or others use of data are the most common barriers to achieving impact from data. Technology and data are rarely in short supply. 

The following section introduces common constraints related to these barriers in delivering FAIR and safeguarded data within investments and what needs to be done to overcome each.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Cultural resistance to sharing data, driven by concerns of data security and mis-trust in data or others use of data are the most common barriers to achieving impact from data. Technology and data are rarely in short supply.

The following section introduces common constraints related to these barriers in delivering FAIR and safeguarded data within investments and what needs to be done to overcome each.

_graphic.attribution: Designed by macrovector / Freepik [CC-BY]

title: Common constraints (1): Data sharing and access
Common constraints (1): Data sharing and access
body:
One of the biggest barriers is the lack of cultural willingness to share data. This scenario is common where policies and process are not equal in focus to technology. 

Within grants this could look like; no data sharing mechanisms or a lack of confidence in them, silo’s within organisations or governments meaning processes and approaches differ or changes in leadership impacting investment in sharing. 

In this scenario, policies and processes are restrictive and do not support the sharing and reuse of data. This results in a closed (or walled garden) environment which can greatly reduce innovation capabilities and prevent data reaching those who can benefit from fair and equitable access. 

Developing, enforcing and adhering to policies and processes that support data sharing and access is key to overcome this constraint.

title: Common constraints (2): Security and privacy
body:
Another common barrier is a lack of trust in others' use of data. This scenario is common where people are not equal in focus to technology. 

Within grants this could look like; a lack of trust and understanding among stakeholders, limited understanding of key data concepts, or a lack of understanding of national, regional or international data policies or legislation.

This is most prevalent in situations where people have unaddressed fears arising from legitimate concerns – such as data security, privacy and trust over who has access to data and how it might be used. 

Supporting people with key data literacy skills is critical to help people overcome their fears and show how aspects such as data protection regulations, data security and licensing can in fact support the wider sharing of data.

title: Showcasing benefits: Examples of FAIR and safeguarded data
body: The following are a selection of projects implementing or moving towards implementation of FAIR and safeguarded data in the agricultural sector. You can read more about each in the associated case study document.

_items.title: Data sharing in India
_items.body: The Cereal Systems Initiative for South Asia (CSISA) intended to embed FAIR data in activities, but found challenges in both putting in place the right data sharing agreements and getting support from those who had fears of data security, privacy and trust. Through a series of training courses, accompanied by policy advice, CABI/ODI have supported CSISA and its community to help overcome fears, realise benefits and to put in place new data sharing agreements that ensure data is made as open as possible, while minimising harmful impacts.

_items.title: The BonaRes Repository
_items.body:
BonaRes bring together experts in soil from over 50 institutions to research ways to balance efficient use of soils with protecting the environment with the end goal of supporting farmers to improve decision making. 

To ensure data is findable the team published an open inventory of data they hold using a consistent vocabulary. They also tag all dataset with a licence that clearly outlines reuse rights.

Challenges are still being faced around fears of misuse and trust in the benefits of allow commercial reuse of the data.

_items.title: Case study 3
_items.body: TBC

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]

title: Summary
body:
The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation is committed to information sharing and transparency. In order to deliver on this commitment it is critical to ensure data and information collected, accessed, used or shared within investments is FAIR and safeguarded. That is, data is Findable, Accessible, Interoperable and Reusable to as many people as possible while minimising harmful impact

Key to supporting FAIR and safeguarded data within investments are the people, policies and processes that make use of technology. Maintaining equal focus on all aspects is key to maximize the utility of data. 

The FAIR data toolbox contains key resources that can help everyone deliver FAIR and safeguarded data within investments.

title: Identifying activities
body: Which types of activities will require FAIR and safeguarded data within investments?

_items.text: Those that plan to collect, access, use or share data
Those that plan to use data to inform and drive research and decision making
Those that plan to create or use a digital service (e.g. a platform)
All of the above

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

In today’s digital world, it is highly likely that projects will involve data at some level, and those that don’t will be very rare. This is especially true in research based initiatives that collect and analyse data to discover insight. 

The toolbox contains a checklist that helps identify which investments will require FAIR and safeguarded data within them. The next section introduces this.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

In today’s digital world, it is highly likely that projects will involve data at some level, and those that don’t will be very rare. This is especially true in research based initiatives that collect and analyse data to discover insight. 

The toolbox contains a checklist that helps identify which investments will require FAIR and safeguarded data within them. The next section introduces this.

title: Identifying investments requiring FAIR and safeguarded data
body:
The types of investments that will require FAIR and safeguarded data are those with activities including:

  1. Collecting new data or information - for example, for analysis
  2. Stakeholder collaboration - collaboration between actors often relies on the ability to share data and information between them  
  3. Developing digital services - creating services or applications from data derived from third party sources and transformed in some way to generate insights 
  4. Providing tailored services or insights - tailoring services are like to include personal or sensitive information and will depend on high quality data and evidence and to be able to trust and reuse that data
  5. Sharing or publishing data - an investment may be focussed entirely on improving sharing of data, for example via Soil Information Systems.

The toolbox contains a checklist that helps identify which investments will require FAIR and safeguarded data within them. The checklist builds on the 5 points above, providing examples of activities within each theme.

title: Roles and responsibilities (Program Officers)
body: What is the role of a Program Officer in delivering FAIR and safeguarded data within investments?

_items.text: Identify actions and provide support to ensure data is FAIR and safeguarded within investments.
Regularly benchmark FAIR and safeguarded data within investments to demonstrate progress.
To advise grantees on practical steps to improve data security and privacy
To support grantees to write data sharing agreements

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Whether designing an intervention, technology, product or research study, integrating FAIR and safeguarded data can greatly contribute to the success and impact of an investment. Program Officers should identify actions and provide support to ensure data is FAIR and safeguarded within investments. 

In addition, regularly benchmarking FAIR and safeguarded data within investments can demonstrate progress towards BMGF aims and objectives. To help with this, the toolbox contains a ‘FAIR and safeguarded data progress marker’.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Whether designing an intervention, technology, product or research study, integrating FAIR and safeguarded data can greatly contribute to the success and impact of an investment. Program Officers should identify actions and provide support to ensure data is FAIR and safeguarded within investments. 

In addition, regularly benchmarking FAIR and safeguarded data within investments can demonstrate progress towards BMGF aims and objectives. To help with this, the toolbox contains a ‘FAIR and safeguarded data progress marker’.

title: Roles and responsibilities (Grantees)
body: What is the role of a grantee in ensuring that grants are data transformative?

_items.text: To take responsibility for data transformation in their grants
To ensure compliance with national and international stakeholder and funder policies in delivering data transformation
To ensure activities balance focus on technology with process and capacity building for people
All of the above

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Grantees need to take a key role in delivering FAIR and safeguarded data within investments. Primarily this involves addressing the core constraints, considering and planning for data access, use and sharing from the outset, educating themselves and others to overcome fears and putting in place the policies and processes that will not only support their grant, but lead to increased data utility and return of value from the data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Grantees need to take a key role in delivering FAIR and safeguarded data within investments. Primarily this involves addressing the core constraints, considering and planning for data access, use and sharing from the outset, educating themselves and others to overcome fears and putting in place the policies and processes that will not only support their grant, but lead to increased data utility and return of value from the data.

title: Delivering FAIR and safeguarded data within investments
body: The FAIR data toolbox contains key resources that can help everyone deliver FAIR and safeguarded data within investments. Discover more about each below:

_items.title: The FAIR and safeguarded data progress marker
_items.body: The FAIR and safeguarded data progress marker presents key questions and an accompanying mark scheme. This key tool can help understand progress towards the Foundations commitment to information sharing and transparency, and implementation of the open access policy. It measures progress in delivering FAIR and safeguarded data within investments, while minimising harmful impacts.

_items.title: Learning resources
_items.body:
The toolbox also contains a number of eLearning modules that anyone can access to increase level of understand in how to deliver FAIR and safeguarded data within investments; 

These include:

  • Delivering data enabling investments (this one)
  • Assessing in country policies and laws to support data sharing
  • Working with data from multiple sources
  • Protecting rights of individuals while maximising the utility of data
  • Maximising reuse of data through licensing and sharing
  • Minimising harmful impacts from data
  • Building sustainable data ecosystems

Each is available to everyone, both POs and Grantees, in the toolbox.

_items.title: Tools and checklists to support investments
_items.body:
To support practical implementation and delivery of FAIR and safeguarded data within investments a set of checklists, practical guides and tools are also available in the toolbox. Examples include:

  • Cheat sheet - key pieces of information to reference from the eLearning
  • Checklist: Identifying investments that require FAIR and safeguarded data
  • FAIR data in investments - mark scheme (what does good look like)
  • Case study - FAIR data implementation in real projects

_items.title: Case studies
_items.body: Being able to demonstrate the benefits of FAIR and safeguarded data is key to supporting everyone. The toolbox contains a number of case studies on initiatives from around the world.

_items.title: Specialist support
_items.body: While the FAIR data toolbox is self-serve, we have also listed a set of external support organisations and individuals that can help with all aspects of delivering FAIR and safeguarded data within investments.

title: Common constraints (3): Trust and benefits
body:
In addition to the two challenges we have introduced already, there is a third; trust & benefits. Again this is about people. 

Within investments this could look like; a lack of trust in the data produced, a lack of incentives to collect quality data, data being used as a ‘bargaining chip’, benefits of sharing not well understood or concerns others will unfairly benefit from data collected and shared.

People need to have access to examples of where FAIR and safeguarded data has delivered benefits to all involved.

title: Introduction
body:
There are many factors in-country that can impact on achieving FAIR and safeguarded data within investments and the ecosystem in which they sit. All of them related to our pillars; people, policies and processes and technology. 

A broad set of stakeholders, many within the wider data ecosystem, may also have to be engaged to ensure appropriate political, social, legal and technological frameworks are in place in-country to support FAIR and safeguarded data within investments. 

In some situations, activities might have to focus exclusively on the enabling environment alongside or prior to investing in projects that seek to benefit from FAIR and safeguarded data in domains such as agriculture and health.

_graphic.attribution: Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation [All rights reserved]

title: Topics
body:
The aim of this module is to help ensure that investments are well scoped with respect to the enabling environment.

This module introduces:

  • Factors that contribute to an enabling environment
  • Examples of where activities to support an enabling environment have bought benefit to FAIR and safeguarded data
  • Stakeholders in an enabling environment
  • The role of the Foundation as a stakeholder
  • How to evaluate the enabling environment
  • Choosing actions to support the enabling environment in regards to FAIR and safeguarded data.

title: Factors that contribute to an enabling environment
Factors that disrupt the enabling environment
body:
Factors that could disrupt the enabling environment are the same as common constraints to data use; politics, culture and technological capacity. 

Political tensions, for example over land or borders could restrict data collection in those geographies. Technological capacity can also be impacted by politics, for example internet outages in response to social unrest, restricts communication and the exchange of data and information. 

Cultural sensitivities and/or outdated practices in communities is also a factor. These are often driven by concerns of security and mis-trust in others' use of data. In turn this can restrict enabling policies and legislative frameworks from being created.

title: Factors that disrupt the enabling environment
Stakeholders in enabling environment
body: Which stakeholders have significant influence on the enabling environment?

_items.text: Community leaders, strategists and domain experts
Governments and regulators
Individual business owners e.g. farmers
Suppliers/managers of tools, technologies and services
University students

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

The enabling environment is influenced by the organisations and communities that set the laws, policies and social norms. These include those who create the policies and legislative frameworks, those that encourage particular behaviours, those who advise on best practice, those who supply tools and services using data and those who provide evidence and analyses to help support and refine arguments and approach.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The enabling environment is influenced by the organisations and communities that set the laws, policies and social norms. These include those who create the policies and legislative frameworks, those that encourage particular behaviours, those who advise on best practice, those who supply tools and services using data and those who provide evidence and analyses to help support and refine arguments and approach.

title: Stakeholders roles
body:
The enabling environment is influenced by a range of stakeholders, and in particular, the organisations and communities that set the laws, policies and social norms. 

These include; 

  • regulators who create the policies and legislative frameworks, e.g. governments and funders
  • advocates, such as think tanks and civil society, that encourage particular behaviours
  • international bodies and experts who advise on best practice
  • companies and departments that supply tools and services for working with data e.g. cloud service providers as well as local IT departments   
  • researchers who provide evidence to help support and refine arguments and approach e.g universities
  • citizens and local communities, like business owners and smallholders, whom the laws and policies are shaped to benefit

The laws and policies set by those in a position of influence will affect everyone in the data ecosystem. Consulting or engaging those that may not be more directly involved (e.g. individual business owners, smallholders) in policy development can help ensure those laws and policies comply with social norms and are adopted by the community.

title: The role of the Foundation as a stakeholder
body:
The Foundation can support the enabling environment by;

  • Supporting the people - by improving data literacy and skills, and facilitating engagement with communities that create or are impacted by the data.
  • Supporting the creation of policy and process - by encouraging and facilitating collaboration with domain experts,community leaders and governments to help them chart their own path.
  • Support access, use and sharing of data by investing in standards and technologies to ensure its long-term sustainability.

title: Summary
body:
There are many factors in-country that can impact on achieving FAIR and safeguarded data within investments and the ecosystem in which they sit. All of them related to our pillars; people, policies and processes and technology.

The Foundation has a role in supporting the enabling environment by investing in initiatives aimed to help leaders and local institutions chart their own path. 

Being aware of the enabling environment is important at all stages of an investment. Ideally an investment will be planned with an understanding of the current enabling environment in-country and proposal development can continue.

Keeping an eye on the in-country context and any changes in the political, legal, social and technological landscape will also help maximise the impact of the investment or even help identify new areas for investment.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]

title: The enabling environment
body: Which of these factors contribute to an enabling environment to support FAIR and safeguarded data?

_items.text: Policies, legal and regulatory frameworks relevant internationally or to the country, region or domain
Community norms and practices
Access to technologies to collect, access, use and share data
All of the above

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

An enabling environment is primarily supported by the policies, legal and regulatory frameworks relevant to the country or domain (e.g. medicine). Understanding and engaging with communities norms is important both to ensure the expectations of those represented by or impacted by the data are met, and to ensure processes that support FAIR and safeguarded data are appropriate for the communities collecting, accessing, using or sharing the data. Collectively the policies and processes, communities of people and access to technology shape how data is collected, accessed, used and shared. Together these make up the enabling environment.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

An enabling environment is primarily supported by the policies, legal and regulatory frameworks relevant to the country or domain (e.g. medicine). Understanding and engaging with communities norms is important both to ensure the expectations of those represented by or impacted by the data are met, and to ensure processes that support FAIR and safeguarded data are appropriate for the communities collecting, accessing, using or sharing the data. Collectively the policies and processes, communities of people and access to technology shape how data is collected, accessed, used and shared. Together these make up the enabling environment.

title: Factors that contribute to an enabling environment
body: There may be good reasons that some communities are resistant to sharing data. Common considerations include concerns of security and mis-trust in others' use of data. These and other considerations can restrict enabling policies, processes and legislative frameworks from being created.
instruction: There are many factors that contribute to an enabling environment, common ones include;

_items.title: Policies, legal and regulatory frameworks
_items.body:
Open data or data sharing and access policies

Data protection laws

Rights and freedoms of citizens to make use of data

Regulations on transparency and data sharing (for example tensions over land or borders could restrict data collection in those geographies)

Competition laws

_items.title: Community norms and practices
_items.body:
Adoption/misinterpretation of legal and regulatory frameworks

Domain specific policies (e.g. professional codes of conduct)

Ethical codes of practice

Adoption of standards and common practices for collection, storage and sharing of data

Embargo periods

Cultural considerations

_items.title: Access to technology
_items.body:
Availability or reliability of the internet 

Availability of technology (nationally or institutionally) 

Level of access to procure and pay for technology

title: Examples of supporting an enabling environment
displayTitle: Examples of supporting an enabling environment
body: Explore the following examples of where activities have focussed on supporting an enabling environment to unlock value from FAIR and safeguarded data:

_items.title: Supporting the Government in Ethiopia
_items.body:
In Ethiopia, the Ministry of Agriculture is attempting to achieve an ambitious goal to map the country’s soil and compile in-depth soil fertility information. However, the enabling environment is complex due to the existence of multiple organisations with overlapping remits and no regulatory framework for sharing data. 

Enabled by positive changes in the government’s attitude to the sharing of geospatial data, the Ministry of Agriculture engaged international development agencies, including the Foundation, and external data experts to support the development of a data sharing policy to address these issues.

_items.title: Tackling fears in India
_items.body:
Funded by the Foundation and USAID, the Cereal Systems Initiative for South Asia (CSISA) was established in 2009 with goals including improving farmers’ access to market information. 

The enabling environment here was impacted by a widespread concern around misuse of data and lack of data management processes. CSISA convened domain experts, research institutions and public sector bodies to establish a steering committee to connect institutions together to start to unlock the benefits of wider data sharing for everyone. Assisted by the foundation, this community was able to improve their data knowledge and skills to tackle barriers and fears and develop community norms and practices to ensure data is accessible and reusable for as many people as possible.

_items.title: Building skills in Tanzania
_items.body:
In Tanzania, the Ramini Huria project trained local stakeholders in how to create highly accurate maps of the most flood-prone areas of the city.

In order to address concerns over data stewardship and ownership, those involved in the project were trained in the benefits of working with open platforms including OpenStreetMap, ensuring that data remains available and usable by everyone, including local governments and authorities, beyond the end of the project.

title: The role of the Foundation as a stakeholder
Evaluating the enabling environment
body:
Conducting a broad landscape review of data policies and legislative frameworks relevant to the geography, relationships with state governments and technological capacity can provide insight into the feasibility of an investment involving FAIR and safeguarded data. It can help by;

  • flagging any major legal or regulatory barriers to the use of data in projects
  • flagging cultural considerations and norms when starting a new investment process in a country or region
  • maximising the impact  by ensuring investments are designed in respect to the enabling environment
  • Identify opportunities for investments that directly support the wider enabling environment

title: Completing a data country profile
body:
Grantees should be evaluating the enabling environment and developing their own understanding of how the environment enables their specific grant. A  template guide to help conduct such a landscape review and create a ‘Country Data Profile’ is available in the toolbox. 

A country data profile can be completed by a Program Officer, grantee, the Foundation in-country team or a third party. It is likely to require desk research and engagement with stakeholders in-country, especially if availability of information online is sparse. 

Click here to download the country data profile guide

title: Identifying next steps
body: Which actions do you take if the enabling environment in-country is not compatible at all, or in part, with the needs of FAIR and safeguarded data?

_items.text: Pause the proposal until the enabling environment is suitable
Amend proposal so it works with in the constraints of the enabling environment
Engage relevant stakeholders to consider how to overcome the challenges
Highlight where there are structural issues that can't be addressed within the investment and may need other, more strategic interventions
All of the above

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

The reason that data is not FAIR and safeguarded is not always obvious; it may not be simply because a platform to hold data does not exist. Following an evaluation of the enabling environment it may be necessary to pause or amend a proposal in order to focus on building an enabling environment.  The Foundation has a role in influencing the enabling environment by investing in initiatives aimed to help leaders and local institutions chart their own path. This may involve engaging more widely, or with different sets of stakeholders, making strategic interventions in areas to enable successful investments in others.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The reason that data is not FAIR and safeguarded is not always obvious; it may not be simply because a platform to hold data does not exist. Following an evaluation of the enabling environment it may be necessary to pause or amend a proposal in order to focus on building an enabling environment.  The Foundation has a role in influencing the enabling environment by investing in initiatives aimed to help leaders and local institutions chart their own path. This may involve engaging more widely, or with different sets of stakeholders, making strategic interventions in areas to enable successful investments in others.

title: When to evaluate
body: During the INVEST process, when should the enabling environment be evaluated?

_items.text: At concept stage only
At project proposal stage only
Never
Throughout the duration of the investment

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Being aware of the enabling environment is important at all stages of an investment. Ideally an investment will be planned with an understanding of the current enabling environment in-country and proposal development can continue.

Keeping an eye on the in-country context and any changes in the political, legal, social and technological landscape will also help maximise the impact of the investment or even help identify new areas for investment.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Being aware of the enabling environment is important at all stages of an investment. Ideally an investment will be planned with an understanding of the current enabling environment in-country and proposal development can continue.

Keeping an eye on the in-country context and any changes in the political, legal, social and technological landscape will also help maximise the impact of the investment or even help identify new areas for investment.

title: Enabling environments: Evaluate, engage, enable
body:
Evaluate and monitor
Ideally an investment will be planned with an understanding of the current enabling environment in-country and proposal development can continue. Regardless of this, it is important to evaluate and monitor the enabling environment for any changes in the political, legal, institutional and technological landscape, during proposal development and when the grant is active. 

Engage and support
When there are issues that can't be addressed within the investment (for example a lack of frameworks governing use of data) other, more strategic interventions like engaging and supporting governments, may be needed. In this instance it may be sensible to pause the proposal or amend it to work within the constraints of the enabling environment. 

Enable investments
When parts of the enabling environment are compatible with the proposal, but others aren’t it may be possible to amend the proposal so it works within the constraints of the enabling environment.

title: Who can help
body: Evaluating and continually monitoring the enabling environment can be a complex, time demanding task. Who can help with the process?

_items.text: Foundation business partners
Grantees
In-country staff and associates
External experts
All of the above

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

The same list of stakeholders from before are just some of the people who can help you understand the enabling environment. These are the regulators, advocates, international bodies and experts, companies that provide services, researchers, citizens and local communities.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The same list of stakeholders from before are just some of the people who can help you understand the enabling environment. These are the regulators, advocates, international bodies and experts, companies that provide services, researchers, citizens and local communities.

title: What to do when things are unclear
Considering compatibility with existing national, regional, local and funder policies
displayTitle: Considering compatibility with existing national, regional, local and funder policies
body:
Even when you have established what permissions you have to reuse a single dataset, things can get complex when you wish to combine datasets together, or you have existing in-country policies or funder policies (such as the BMGF open access policy) that also set conditions related to FAIR and safeguarded data. 

For example, such policies might set out incompatible terms and conditions, for example requiring data to be available for commercial reuse or explicitly blocking it. Other conflicts may be related to embargo periods either being required or not.

Concessions may have to be sought from one or more of the parties involved.  The Foundation has a role in influencing the enabling environment by investing in initiatives aimed to help leaders and local institutions chart their own path. 

The FAIR data toolbox contains a guide on considering data rights & permissions in investments to help with this.

title: The role of the Foundation as a stakeholder
body:
Following these checks, further processing will likely be required to:

  • Check the data for, and deal with, any errors
  • Remove unneeded data
  • Transform the format or structure of the data
  • Apply techniques such as anonymisation and suppression to minimise harmful impacts in the data prior to use
  • Combining or enriching the data with other data sources.

title: Summary
body:
Digitally-enabled services rely on sustainable access to relevant data, provided in a way that enables integration, analysis and reuse. Building on top of existing data saves significant time in collecting data that already exists. 

Even if the data exists and is well maintained, often those who hold it will not have clear policies and processes in place to support the sharing and reuse of data. Working with stakeholders who hold data, or have a wider role in putting in place policies and processes for data sharing, from early on in proposal development is essential to ensure the appropriate mechanisms are put in place (or enforced) to support the access to and sharing of data.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]

title: A spectrum of data rights
body: To help explain the complex landscape of data rights, the Open Data Institute has produced the Data Spectrum which neatly illustrates the different types of data, from closed, through shared to open.
instruction: Click on the pins to find out more about each type of data

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]

_items.title: Closed / Limited data
_items.body:
Closed data covers data that is only available to a few individuals. Data should be closed if it is necessary to minimise harmful impacts. Examples of closed data include sensitive legal documents, employment contracts and personal health records. Conditions attached to reusing closed data are likely to be very restrictive in order to ensure harmful impacts are minimised.

Examples of closed data: Smallholder finances and pesticide application permits.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]

_items.title: Shared data
_items.body:
Shared data is the largest category and covers everything from medical research data to social network data. In this category, there are often restrictions on who can access and use data. These restrictions can again be necessary to minimise harmful impacts or may be in place to preserve commercial advantage. Reusing shared data will often come with the same restrictions and limit potential reuse and subsequent sharing. 

Examples of shared data: Reports of crop disease.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]

_items.title: Public data
_items.body:
Public data covers all data that is visible to everyone but with limited or unclear rights.  As with the question previously, just because something is visible online, that doesn't mean you can freely make use of it. To reuse public data, it may be necessary to approach the rights holder to establish if it can be reused freely or if there will be restrictions as per shared data. 

Examples of public data: Patented pesticide formulas.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]

_items.title: Open data
_items.body:
Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share. Providing the reuse is legal, open data can be reused without restriction and shared forward with others.

Examples of public data: Earth observations

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]

title: A data spectrum for agriculture
body: The Open Data Institute has produced a version of its popular data spectrum for agriculture. You can access, download and reuse this by clicking here. The FAIR data toolbox also contains an explainer for this data spectrum to help understand how to use and interpret it.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

title: Identifying open, shared and closed data
Identifying open, shared and closed data

_items.text: Dataset available for research purposes only, cannot be used commercially
Data available to original research team only
Dataset available to download as an excel file
Dataset available for anyone to download and use, can even be used to develop revenue generating applications

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

The more open the dataset, the less barriers there are to reuse. If datasets are not open, then some negotiation may be required with the owner to see what can be done to ensure third party data can be used in a way compatible with the policies and processes set out in the conditions of the grant or those in country. This could include helping data owners to address any concerns they have related to data sharing or to set up a data sharing agreement. 

Additionally, reuse is highly likely to be impacted by the most restrictive licence under which data is obtained from  a third party. For example if you combine two open datasets with one available under a non-commercial restriction then the reuse of the resultant combined data is limited to non-commercial use. Care should be taken to ensure source datasets are as open as possible and as closed as necessary to minimise harmful impacts.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The more open the dataset, the less barriers there are to reuse. If datasets are not open, then some negotiation may be required with the owner to see what can be done to ensure third party data can be used in a way compatible with the policies and processes set out in the conditions of the grant or those in country. This could include helping data owners to address any concerns they have related to data sharing or to set up a data sharing agreement. 

Additionally, reuse is highly likely to be impacted by the most restrictive licence under which data is obtained from  a third party. For example if you combine two open datasets with one available under a non-commercial restriction then the reuse of the resultant combined data is limited to non-commercial use. Care should be taken to ensure source datasets are as open as possible and as closed as necessary to minimise harmful impacts.

title: Obtaining rights to reuse third party data
displayTitle: Obtaining rights to reuse third party data
body:
By default, anything that involves an ‘intellectual effort’ in its creation is copyright protected; the creator has exclusive rights to that creation. In order for anyone else to reuse that creation they must be given permission from the rights holder (in this case the creator).

Such permissions usually come in the form of data sharing agreements or licences. It is important to ensure that permissions to access, use and share data are clear. Clarity comes from having explicit licences and agreements to use third-party content, understanding relevant legal restrictions or permissions.

If datasets are not open, then some negotiation may be required with the owner to see what can be done to ensure third party data can be used in a way compatible with the policies and processes set out in the conditions of the grant or those in country. This could include helping data owners to address any concerns they have related to data sharing or to set up a data sharing agreement.

title: What to do when things are unclear
body:
In some cases, the rights and permissions related to a dataset might be unclear and an owner not listed. Following investigation you might even be bounced between people and get nowhere.

In this situation, data may still be usable and this use covered by a fair use (or fair dealing) exception or other local law.

If this is not the case, then a risk based decision could be made over the collection, use and sharing of the data. This is done with the understanding that the owner could reemerge and it may be necessary to backtrack, negotiate continued use, or potentially face a legal challenge.

title: Considering reusability of data from third party sources
body:
This may involve:

  • Ensuring third party data is using standards compatible with your needs. This might include standards for how the data is collected, the units of collection as well as how the data is represented and exchanged
  • Checking coverage. Does the data actually relate to what you require. 
  • The timeliness of the data:  Does it cover the right period, is it up to date?
  • The granularity of the data. Is it as precise and include enough detail to be used in the ways intended?

title: A decision making flowchart for using data from third party sources
displayTitle: A decision making flowchart for using data from third party sources

title: Understanding the stakeholders and roles within a data ecosystem
displayTitle: Understanding the stakeholders and roles within a data ecosystem
body: Can you match the following descriptions with the right stakeholders within the ecosystem in relation to reuse of data from third party sources?

_items.text: Reuser of data to help develop and scale solutions based upon insights for consumers, needs to ensure rights and permissions to use data within solutions.
Responsible for ensuring everyone in the grant ecosystem has the appropriate rights and permission to access, use and share data, to ensure success of the grant.
Collector and reuser of data. Collects and analyses raw data, needs to ensure that rights and permissions are obtained and provided that allow the storage, use and sharing of the data with others.
Data steward. In charge of managing a number of key national datasets, needs to provide permissions for others to use the data and protect the rights of those the data is about.

Responsible for delivering FAIR and safeguarded data within investments. This includes ensuring that investments deliver impact and are in line with objectives and policies, and supporting the grantee through capacity building and facilitating conversations with other stakeholders in the data ecosystem where necessary.
Responsible for national policies on data and information. These contribute to the enabling environment in-country and set expectations on access, use and sharing of data.

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

There are many stakeholders in a data ecosystem, some will be directly involved in an investment while many important stakeholders will be external or even international. It is the responsibility of the lead organisation to understand the environment, engage stakeholders and work with program officers to ensure that the best possible outcomes are achieved and that data is FAIR and safeguarded.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

There are many stakeholders in a data ecosystem, some will be directly involved in an investment while many important stakeholders will be external or even international. It is the responsibility of the lead organisation to understand the environment, engage stakeholders and work with program officers to ensure that the best possible outcomes are achieved and that data is FAIR and safeguarded.

title: Mapping data ecosystems
body:
Key to ensuring data is FAIR and safeguarded are the people, policies and processes that support the use of technology. Many of the people are likely to be third party stakeholders and understanding the roles they play can be complex. Creating a map of a data ecosystem can help us to identify the key people, the relationships between them and the different roles they play. 

Representing ecosystems visually can be particularly useful when contexts are complex, not well understood or not yet fully developed.

title: Mapping data spectrums
body:
A data ecosystem map also can be used to describe how data is being shared across The Data Spectrum. A map can show how data is being used to deliver a service, or show where data is not being shared. Understanding where value is or may be created from shared data will inform conversations with third parties on rights and permissions to reuse data.

The FAIR data toolbox contains a link to guides to help understand personas in agricultural ecosystems and a guide to mapping data ecosystems. The related materials on assessing the enabling environment should also be referred to when ensuring appropriate political, social, legal and technological frameworks are in place in-country to support FAIR and safeguarded data within investments.

title: Introduction
body:
Digitally-enabled services rely on sustainable access to relevant data, provided in a way that enables integration, analysis and reuse. Such services often require data from multiple third parties to even function, such as geographic data, population and socioeconomic data or sample data from previous projects. 

However, reusing data from existing third party sources can be complex and face many challenges. Grant proposals that set out with good intentions to reuse existing data often encounter many barriers which should be addressed as soon as possible. 

This module looks at the different barriers and techniques to address each.

_graphic.attribution: Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation [All rights reserved]

title: Topics
body:
This module introduces:

  • The value of reusing data from third party sources
  • Barriers in reusing data from third party sources
  • The importance of rights and permissions in data
  • A spectrum of data rights
  • Identifying open, shared and closed data
  • Obtaining rights to reuse third party data
  • Considering compatibility with existing country and funder policies
  • Considering reliability and interoperability of data from third party sources
  • A decision making flowchart for using data from third party sources
  • The roles of different stakeholders in the data ecosystem
  • How to map a data ecosystem

title: The value of reusing data from third party sources
The value of reusing data from third party sources
body: Why use data from third party sources?

_items.text: Saves time in collecting data that already exists
Allows you to build upon and take advantage of existing investment in data collection
Allows you to benefit from investment in data governance & allows faster prototyping or research, by reducing time required to source necessary data
All of the above

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Digitally-enabled services rely on sustainable access to relevant data, provided in a way that enables integration, analysis and reuse. More than this, building on top of existing data saves significant time in collecting data that already exists. Building good relationships with data holders also means that you can build upon and take advantage of existing activities and communities around the data to support your aims. Furthermore, if the data is well maintained and of good quality, less of your own time will be required to prepare data prior to reuse. Encouraging reuse can help to reduce cost of investment and increase ROI from previous investment in data collection and platforms.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Digitally-enabled services rely on sustainable access to relevant data, provided in a way that enables integration, analysis and reuse. More than this, building on top of existing data saves significant time in collecting data that already exists. Building good relationships with data holders also means that you can build upon and take advantage of existing activities and communities around the data to support your aims. Furthermore, if the data is well maintained and of good quality, less of your own time will be required to prepare data prior to reuse. Encouraging reuse can help to reduce cost of investment and increase ROI from previous investment in data collection and platforms.

title: Barriers in reusing data from third party sources

_graphic.attribution: Designed by macrovector / Freepik [CC-BY]

title: Barriers in reusing data from third party sources
body: The list below contains common barriers to reusing data from third party sources, which do you think is the most common?

_items.text: A lack of processes and policies to share data
Data is not maintained
Data in wrong format or structure
Data is incomplete

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Even if the data exists and is well maintained, often those who hold it will not have clear policies and processes in place to support the sharing and reuse of data. This is most commonly due to concerns about risks and impacts related to the sharing of data. Working with stakeholders who hold data from early on in proposal development is essential to ensure the appropriate mechanisms are put in place (or enforced) to support the access to and sharing of data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Even if the data exists and is well maintained, often those who hold it will not have clear policies and processes in place to support the sharing and reuse of data. This is most commonly due to concerns about risks and impacts related to the sharing of data. Working with stakeholders who hold data from early on in proposal development is essential to ensure the appropriate mechanisms are put in place (or enforced) to support the access to and sharing of data.

title: The importance of rights and permissions in data
The importance of rights and permissions in data
body: All data available on the web is open and free to use. True or false?

_items.text: True
False

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Just because something can be accessed over the internet does not mean that it is free to use. For example, it is easy to screenshot or download company logos but these cannot then simply be used freely by anyone – the owner must grant permission for use. Unless it is published under a licence that allows reuse.

The same is true for data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Just because something can be accessed over the internet does not mean that it is free to use. For example, it is easy to screenshot or download company logos but these cannot then simply be used freely by anyone – the owner must grant permission for use. Unless it is published under a licence that allows reuse.

The same is true for data.

title: Introduction
body:
Some of the biggest barriers to delivering FAIR and safeguarded data within investments can be concerns of data security and privacy along with a mis-trust in data or others use of data. Understanding risks and being able to evaluate the real and perceived impact is critical to overcoming these barriers, increasing confidence in wider sharing of data while minimising harmful impacts.

This module introduces:

  • How to identify risks
  • Linking risks to impact
  • Analysing likelihood and severity
  • The impacts of NOT sharing data
  • Categories of risks and impact
  • Identifying risks in data
  • Strategies to help minimise risks
  • Tools to help identify and manage risk

_graphic.attribution: Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation [All rights reserved]

title: Summary
body:
Common challenges to delivering FAIR and safeguarded data within investments are concerns of data security and privacy along with a mis-trust in data or other use of data. Understanding risks and being able to evaluate the real and perceived impact is critical to overcoming these challenges, increasing confidence in wider sharing of data while minimising harmful impacts. 

There are many risks and impacts associated with data, such as low quality data leading to reputational damage. However when managed carefully the likelihood and severity of impact from these risks could in fact be very low. There are negative impacts that can result from not sharing data, so it is important to also carefully consider these when doing any form of risk assessment for data. 

Key strategies to minimise impact from risks include: 

  • Supporting people with data literacy
  • Developing, enforcing and adhering to policies and processes for both data sharing as well as data protection.
  • Implementing data management plans
  • Being open in communication with stakeholders
  • Regularly reviewing risks and acting accordingly

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]

title: Identifying risks and concerns
body: Which of the following are risks or concerns associated with sharing data?

_items.text: Data being of bad quality
Data getting into the wrong hands (e.g. a competitor)
Personal or sensitive information in the data
All of the above

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

There are many risks or concerns that arise only when data is shared, such as data getting into the wrong hands. Others apply regardless of if the data is shared with others, such as bad quality data and handling of personal information. However while some concerns stem from real risks, such as reputational damage or breaking the law, the perceived and likely impact from others may be inflated.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

There are many risks or concerns that arise only when data is shared, such as data getting into the wrong hands. Others apply regardless of if the data is shared with others, such as bad quality data and handling of personal information. However while some concerns stem from real risks, such as reputational damage or breaking the law, the perceived and likely impact from others may be inflated.

title: The terminology of risks
body:
Sometimes it’s hard to work out how we’re going to address and minimise risk. The most common reason for this is because we haven’t described the risk correctly. To decide how we’re going to minimise a risk, we first need to define some key elements. These are:

  • An action: the thing we want to do
  • A concern: something that might go wrong
  • A cause: the reason it might go wrong
  • An impact: the result if it goes wrong

All of these together make up the risk.

title: Risks: What can you control?
body: These four elements make up the risk. If I want to minimise risk, which of these elements is something you can control or affect?

_items.text: Action
Concern
Cause
Impact

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

The impact is the only element of the risk that is NOT directly under  your control. Many risks start as concerns about something that hasn’t yet happened, these concerns need to be evaluated to identify if they are (1) Genuine, (2) Likely and (3) Severe. Following this, causes can be addressed and appropriate actions taken to minimise negative impact.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The impact is the only element of the risk that is NOT directly under  your control. Many risks start as concerns about something that hasn’t yet happened, these concerns need to be evaluated to identify if they are (1) Genuine, (2) Likely and (3) Severe. Following this, causes can be addressed and appropriate actions taken to minimise negative impact.

title: Identifying actions, concerns, causes and impacts

_items.text: Data getting to the wrong hands
Data not being validated when entered into a system
Someone using the data to harm another individual
